Thanks for realizing this. The article is unbelievably slanted. (Also, I have no problem with Canadians earning as much as Americans -- why should they earn less? why would our ego demand that?)

Instead they picked lower income Americans! Would a Swedish hardware store clerk be making more than $33K? that is the real question and they dodge it.

In the US, a firefighter and a surgical nurse would have a joint income in the low to mid-$100K range and be living VERY well.
Germany,  France,  the UK.  Shall I go on?
But the Americans want to live the American dream. How can you deny them that? Nice brainwashing, isn't it?

Kurt in Switzerland

I cannot speak for Swedish firefighters, but I know some American ones. They start at $60K or more, in their early 20s. By their 30s, they are earning lose to $100K. They work only 24 hours a week and have generous vacations -- by the 10 year point, it is four weeks or more. (It's not as if Swedes get 5 weeks and we get NONE, lol.) They can also "trade" working shifts with other firefighters to get longer vacations.

By 46, they are eligible for a full retirement at 90% of final salary, and that's a public pension which can't be reduced or eliminated. Many firefighters retire wealthy. Their short hours let them have a good second job between shifts. Some earn two pensions that way.

If you think US firefighters work a 40 hour week, or get 2 weeks of vacation and earn minimum wage -- you are so out of touch that we can't even compare the US to Sweden in an intelligent fashion.

I have not spent enough time in Europe to be able to say (though surely someone has and could give more specific info!), but I live on the US/Canada border and have visited there many times -- big cities and rural countryside.

Canada is a great place that I enjoy visiting. But its pretty expensive compared to the US. For decades, Canadians on the border have come to the US to shop due to our cheaper prices. This was even true when the Canadian dollar was 30% less than the US dollar -- that's how big the disparity was.

Pharmaceuticals may be cheaper (due to government intervention with Big Pharma) but everything else is more -- food is more costly. Taxes are higher. Restaurants and theaters cost more. Gasoline was always MUCH higher.

When we went the most was in the 80s and early 90s, when the 30% advantage made the vacation relatively cheap. Today, it is pretty expensive to visit Canada vs. a similar trip in the US. And you need a passport. So we go much less. Still, it is obviously more costly. And when you come back to the US, you can file to get your VAT on purchases refunded -- that's when you see how costly that VAT tax is. It's HUGE. I do not believe Americans would willingly pay such a huge national sales tax, not even for "free" health are or college.

I have had a foot in both countries for over 10 years and here are my thoughts. Canada, yes we pay taxes on income, the U.S. rattles the sword of lower income taxes, but god forbid you own property in NY state! You can always shelter income, but forget running from the property assessor.
Education - at an undergraduate level, is a 4 year degree worth at the top end $200,000 in a thin job market, vis a vis a max $50K expense in Canada where you will probably make more out year 1? It takes a long time to pay off $150,000.
Health - I watched my mother (Canadian) and my mother-in-law (American pass away within 12 months of each other with the same condition which was basically inoperable. My mother was made comfortable, my mother-in-law was kept on life support for a much longer time. I'm not God, but the end was coming for both. Mom's expense, "0", mother-in-laws, $20K. Just some food for thought.

American workers get two weeks vacation to START. Most people have been at their jobs much longer than that -- they get an average of 3-5 weeks, with many getting six weeks.

Until my husband was laid off in 2001, he got six weeks paid vacation yearly. He found a new job and is back up to 4 weeks. Swedes get 5 weeks. That is not exactly a vast difference.

I would like to direct those who with the Supreme Court majority to a Bloomberg View article entitled: "The Dark Chain of Events to Your Kid's Ivy League Rejection" by Stephen Mihm

"Despite their perfect grade-point averages and SAT scores and stellar extracurricular activities, the number of top-achieving high school seniors who made the cut at the most elite universities reached record lows this year. Stanford, for example, only admitted 5 percent of applicants, the fewest in its history; other top institutions reported similar numbers.

This may look like meritocracy reaching its ultimate rarefaction, yet the motives that led top colleges and universities to introduce highly selective admissions a century ago were far from lofty. The aim was to keep out one group in particular: Jews."

Professor Mihm's article and inline links, provide a well-rounded historical and current overview of the very intricate set of issues facing millions of students.

http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2014-04-21/the-dark-chain-of-event...

I am an old mountain climber from the Outward Mountain Organization with a motto of " Perseverance". Where the rules were you carry your own equipment, food, clothing, and everything else for a 21 days expedition and be responsible to your self a team of 9 others and each others. Of course climbing and conquering the mountain / final ascent was the goal, but the most important factor was character building and being able to live , communicate and orient with others of different cultures. There were no porters or others for meager wages to haul what others needed. The guides were volunteers from previous expeditions, who enjoyed the spirit and joy of being able to help and guide other for the adventure.
Some $3 to $5 million for the season for the Govt of Nepal and some 5% for the Sherpas is peanuts. People willing to pay some over $100,000 to some middleman organization and go climb Mt. Everest is indeed insult to humanity. For our US and other nations, where their rich citizens can afford something like $100.000 for the luxury of climbing Mt. Everest. These Govt. should immediately contribute some $100 million to these Sherpas , who died. The idea being is to establish an organization, were interested people can enroll for such expeditions and not hire Sherpas as slaves to be porters etc and in the process, risk their lives for these arrogant, selfish and egotistical summit ambitions,

The whole circus that is Everest's SE route needs to be restructured, and Sherpas given a fairer slice of profits here, and on the other 8000ers and lesser peaks in Nepal. As pointed out in the article the Sherpas - and this includes not just ethnic Sherpas but also Gurungs (I believe one of the deceased is a Gurung), Tamang, etcetera (yes and Bahun and Chetri) - are routinely placed first in danger's way - and repeatedly. Need ropes fixed? Send the Sherpas. Someone lost high on the SE ridge? Send the Sherpas to look for them. Need to drag an inexperienced climber up to the summit, one who paid $70,000 with a promise from a Wester "expedition" company that they would do all they could to guarantee success? Send two Sherpas. Sure they make a good living by Nepalese standards - but this isn't something you do all your life. You have to work your way up from being a porter, buy a license from the government, get equipment, and hopefully work from your early twenties until about forty or so - older if you are lucky. And with repeated dangers, every spring and sometimes fall as well - your chances of living 20 years while doing this work on the big E, and other big peaks, well the odds are that you will have an accident somewhere, often because Western climbers don't want to take the sharp end of the rope.

If they made a new rule that for every Sherpa team there must be a Westerner leading, or co-leading, that might change some teams' assessment of the objective danger.
